title-group.article-title: Risk behaviour, parental background, and wealth: A cluster analysis among Swedish boys and girls in the HBSC study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Health Sciences, Mid Sweden University, Sundsvall, Sweden
2Research and Development Centre for the County Council of Västernorrland, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Heidi Carlerby, Department of Health Sciences, Mid Sweden University, SE-851 70 Sundsvall, Sweden. E-mail: heidi.carlerby@miun.se

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 the Nordic Societies of Public Health
permissions.copyright-holder: Associations of Public Health in the Nordic Countries Regions

sec.title: Aim:
sec.p: To analyse how health risk behaviours (HRB) are clustered and associated with parental background and family wealth among Swedish boys and girls.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Data were collected from Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), a global cross-sectional survey for 1997/98, 2001/02, and 2005/06. A total of 11,972 boys and girls in grades 5, 7, and 9 participated in the study. The pupils were categorised in subgroups according to parental background: Swedish (80.0%), mixed (10.6%), and foreign (9.4%). Cluster analyses were used to identify HRB profiles. Multinomial logistic regression analysis was used to estimate associations between cluster allocation, parental background, and family affluence.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: In total 11,232 pupils were identified and allocated to five cluster profiles, half of them in the cluster profile of low-risk behaviour. The most disadvantaged cluster was multiple HRB, which was characterised by high prevalence of smoking, drunkenness, low physical activity, and high soft-drink consumption. The cluster profile of multiple HRB was associated with both mixed background and foreign background in girls and with mixed background in boys. The cluster profile of inadequate tooth brushing was associated with foreign background in both boys and girls. The cluster profiles of multiple HRB and inadequate tooth brushing were associated with low family affluence in girls.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The cluster profiles of multiple HRB and inadequate tooth brushing were associated with parental foreign extraction in boys and girls and with low family affluence in girls. Prevention programmes based on identified clusters of HRB, including consideration of impact of socio-demographic indicators, are needed.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The adolescence period includes challenging normative behaviours, identity formation, and autonomy from the parents, which for some also might include experimenting with tobacco, alcohol, diet, hygiene habits, and physical activity as well as other positive health and risk behaviours [1]. There is an important difference between risk behaviour and health behaviour, as health behaviours (such as tooth brushing habits and mealtime routines) are established in early childhood when the parental influence is strong, while risk behaviours (such smoking and alcohol consumption) are established during the adolescence when the parental impact has decreased [2]. Regular activities such as eating dinner together with the family functions as maintaining health behaviours and protects from health risk behaviours (HRB) [3]. Dealing with risk behaviours is for adolescents a stage in the psychosocial developmental process, but considered as unwanted and harmful behaviours by adults [4,5]. However, components in the social context, such as relations with parents and peers, racial inequalities, gender, economy, and school environment influence social behaviours and the ways in which adolescents approaches risk behaviours [6,7]. Gender studies by Sen and Östlin [8] claim that the choice of a certain lifestyle is dependent on social constructions and power relations, e.g. gender, class, and ethnicity.

For adolescents of foreign extraction, the social context also includes influences of the parents’ culture of origin [9–11], especially for adolescents of mixed background [6,12]. Previous studies have shown that the parents’ religion and country of origin influence boys’ and girls’ alcohol preferences [6,9,12]. Pupils in Sweden with parents of Turkish or Middle Eastern origin [9] or from a Muslim background in the Netherlands, especially the girls [12], consume less alcohol than pupils of the majority population. Some studies have shown high alcohol consumption among pupils of mixed background [6] and those of Finnish origin in Sweden [9]. Some cross-national gendered differences in health behaviours have been shown. In countries where increased alcohol consumption was estimated and boys previously consumed more alcohol than girls, the gap between boys and girls has been reduced [13]. Girls consume more vegetables and less soft drink than boys [14–16]. Boys engage more frequently in physical activities than girls do [17]. In a Swedish study, similar gender differences regarding physical activity were shown [18]. Nevertheless, insufficient daily physical activity was significantly associated with low family wealth in Swedish boys, but not in girls [2]. One of the gender differences regarding body image is that girls are more engaged than boys in behaviour concerning weight [5,18]. Regarding dental health, previous research has shown a connection between family wealth [19], personal wellbeing, school satisfaction, and good oral hygiene, as well as differences in oral hygiene habits between boys and girls, as girls report a higher tooth brushing frequency than boys [2,20]. Swedish research shows inequities in access to dental health care and dental health among minority populations [19]. Recent studies show connections between socioeconomic position and alcohol consumption [13,21] and smoking [7]. Social variables generate protective health factors as well as health risk factors and should account for a comprehensive whole in the adolescents’ daily environment: i.e. one single risk behaviour cannot be isolated from another. Instead, risk behaviours should be seen as syndromes or concepts of lifestyle [1]. The inconsistency in previous research about how HRB patterns are allocated among pupils, and how socio-demographic indicators influence boys’ and girls’ risk behaviours, illuminates the necessity of deeper research about the interplay between socio- demographic indicators and HRBs. However, some American studies stress the importance of framing health-promoting research and interventions for adolescents by identifying cluster profiles for HRBs as well as dividing boys and girls into subgroups according to ethnic origin [11,22] and grade [22]. Ding and Young [22] identified risk behaviour cluster profiles as a tool for prediction of future HRBs. One of the aims of identifying cluster profiles is to emphasise the risk behaviour patterns that differ between subgroups of adolescents [22]. Cluster analysis makes it possible to analyse pattern profiles instead of single HRB [23], which improves the abilities to identify groups of individuals and thereby increase the effectiveness of health promotion programmes. Knowledge about which health behaviours cluster together is important in planning health-promotion interventions and increases the probabilities of success in the reduction of risk behaviours [23]. Few previous studies have explored a comprehensive picture of adolescents’ clustered HRBs and the associations between gender, parental foreign background, and family wealth.

sec.title: Aim
sec.p: The aim of this study was to analyse how HRBs are clustered and associated with parental background and family wealth among Swedish boys and girls.

sec.title: Sample and procedure
sec.p: Data for the present analyses were collected from the Swedish National Institute of Public Health’s survey “Swedish school children’s health behaviour” which is a part of the World Health Organization (WHO) cross-sectional global survey Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC). The data collection follows the HBSC standardised international research protocol [2]. The sampling methods were carried out by Statistics Sweden in a two-step cluster design. First, clusters in the form of schools or classes were randomised from the whole country. Second, the whole cluster, a school or a class, was invited to participate in the study [25]. Pupils in grades 5, 7, and 9 answered the questionnaires during ordinary school classes. Measurements were included from 1997/98, 2001/02, and 2005/06 because those years included questions about the parents’ country of birth. The response rates for the three measurement occasions were between 85% and 90% [25]. The 10–15% pupils who did not participate were absent from school the day for fulfilment of the questionnaire, were of age outside the target group or had too many missing on single questions/items [25].

The present study includes 11,972 pupils. The distribution of pupils was about 2000 in each gender and grade. The Mid Sweden University Research Ethics Committee approved the study as being in accordance with ethical standards (Dnr: MIUN 209/362).

sec.title: Outcome variables
sec.p: Seven HRBs were selected and analysed as categorical variables for cluster analyses and as dichotomous variables for all other analyses, with low risk as reference (coded 0). Drunkenness was assessed by a question about the number of times that respondents have got drunk in their lifetime. There were five answer options: never or once (coded 0) and twice or more (coded 1) [21]. Smoking was assessed by asking for frequency of smoking per week. There were four answer options: never or less than weekly (coded 0) and every day or at least once a week (coded 1) [7]. Physical activity was assessed by asking how many hours per week out of school time were spent on exercising until getting out of breath or sweaty. There were five answer options: 2 hours or more (coded 0) and 1 hour or less (coded 1) [14]. The question regarding weight concern for the measurement year 1997/98 was worded as “At present are you on diet? and had three answer options: “no” (coded 0), “no but I ought to” (coded 1), and “yes” (coded 1). For the measurement years 2001/02 and 2005/06, the question regarding weight concern was posed “At present, are you on diet or doing something else to lose weight?” and had four answer options: “no” and “no but I ought to increase my weight” (coded 0) and “no but I ought to reduce my weight” and “yes” (coded 1).

The question about tooth brushing frequency had five answer options: more than once a day (coded 0) and once a day or less (coded 1) [20]. Vegetables and soft-drink consumption were assessed by asking how many times a week they eat vegetables and drink soft drinks. There were seven answer options. Vegetable consumption was dichotomised as: once a day or more (coded 0) and less than daily (coded 1) [14]. Soft-drink consumption was dichotomised as: less than daily (coded 0) and once a day or more (coded 1) [14].

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: The pupils’ and their parental background was elicited by questions about their own and their parents’ country of birth. The pupils were split up in groups in two steps (Table I).

tr.td: Pupils of one Swedish-born and one foreign-born parent
One Swedish and one Nordic-born parent
One Swedish and one European-born parent (Nordic excluded)
One Swedish and one parent born outside of Europe
Both parents born outside of Europe
Other combinations of two foreign-born parents

sec.p: Pupils with two native-born Swedish parents were used as reference category (coded 0), pupils with one Swedish-born and one foreign-born parent were classified as of mixed background (coded 1), and pupils with two foreign-born parents were classified as of foreign background (coded 2) [26]. Foreign extraction is used as an overall concept and includes both pupils of mixed background and those of foreign background [26]. The material wealth in the household was assessed by family affluence scale (FAS). The instrument includes four questions regarding the number of cars and computers in the household, whether the pupils have their own bedroom, and number of holiday trips made together with the family during the last 12 months [27]. The FAS variable was categorised as: high, 6–7 points (coded 0), middle, 4–5 points (coded 1), and low, 0–3 points (coded 2). The FAS instrument is validated by Boyce et al. [28] and shows adequate fit. Grade and period of measurement were included as control variables. Grade was categorised as grade 5 (coded 0), grade 7, (coded 1), and grade 9 (coded 2). Period of measurement was categorised as 1997/98 (coded 1), 2001/02 (coded 2), and 2005/06 (coded 3).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: SPSS for Windows version 17.0 was used for all statistical analyses. Prevalence was compared with chi-squared tests. Possible interaction effects were tested by interaction terms built upon the five clusters, parental background, and FAS. However, no interaction effects were found. Differences in the three FAS levels were tested pairwise by chi-squared tests. Variance analyses were used to compare number of HRB between subgroups of boys and girls. According to measurement year 2001/02, the design factor for drunkenness was 2.39 and therefore the recommended 99% significance level (p-value <0.01) [25] was used for the HRB. Initially 11,972 respondents were included. In the multinomial analyses, 11,082 respondents remained due to missing values in single items. A p-value <0.01 was accepted as statistically significant in all analyses.

k-mean cluster analyses were conducted as inspired by French et al. [23] and Weden and Zabin [11]. At the first step in the k-mean cluster procedure, all seven HRBs with the original answer options were included and transformed into z-scored variables. Initially we started with 10 clusters. The numbers of clusters were then reduced step by step until the cluster solutions were stable, i.e. had enough individuals and until each cluster had at least one HRB with a z-score >1 standard deviation. The nearest centroid sorting method was used to define clusters [23], with the aim of reaching the nearest mean in each cluster by repeated iterations [29]. To ensure stability within the clusters, hierarchical cluster analyses with a random sample of 33% of the data material were repeated with 10 different random samples. Five random samples showed equality in the mean cluster centres. One was used as an initial cluster centre in the k-mean cluster analyses of the whole data material [30]. Multivariate analyses were conducted using multinomial logistic regression. Outcome variables were the five identified clusters and the low-risk behaviour profile became the reference category. The predictors included were parental background with Swedish background as reference category, and FAS with high family wealth as reference category.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Low FAS was significantly more prevalent in pupils of foreign background (30.3%) than in pupils of Swedish background (8.4%), while pupils of mixed background (14.3%) were in between (p<0.001) [24]. Table II shows means±standard deviations for the number of HRB among the pupils. The overall mean number of HRB was 1.40±1.10. A high mean number of HRB was found in pupils in grade nine (1.77±1.29), in girls of foreign background, (1.66±1.15), in boys of foreign background (1.61±1.23), and in pupils with low FAS, (1.76±1.26).

caption.p: Health risk behaviours (HRB) in boys and girls by parental background, family affluence, and grade: ANOVA analysis.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Due to missing values, the numbers in some cells do not add up to the total base.

sec.p: Five cluster profiles were identified: (1) low-risk behaviour, (2) weight concern, (3) inadequate tooth brushing, (4) drunkenness, and (5) multiple risk behaviours (Table III). The allocation in the cluster profiles shows that half of the pupils had a low-risk behaviour profile. None of the pupils who were allocated to the cluster profile of drunkenness was weekly smokers, but they had a higher rate than average of high soft-drink consumption. It is notable that 97.5% of the pupils who were allocated to the cluster profile of multiple risk behaviour were weekly smokers.

tr.th: Health behaviour profile for the five clusters

fn.p: Values are % (n). Due to missing values, the numbers in some cells do not add up to the total base. The number of respondents included in each single health risk behaviour varied between 11,670 (smoking) and 11,896 (drunkenness).

sec.p: Table IV shows differences in cluster patterns among boys and girls. The boys had a significantly increased probability of allocation to the cluster profiles of inadequate tooth brushing and drunkenness compared with the girls. The girls had a significantly increased probability of allocation to the cluster profiles of weight concern and multiple risk behaviour compared with the boys. Pupils of foreign background showed a higher representation in the cluster profile of inadequate tooth brushing and a lower representation in the cluster profile of drunkenness compared with pupils of Swedish background. Pupils with low FAS showed a higher representation in the cluster profile of multiple risk behaviour compared with pupils of middle or high FAS. More than 95% of the pupils in the cluster profiles of drunkenness and multiple risk behaviour were grade 9 (not shown).

caption.p: Cluster analysis in percentage and numbers by gender, parental background, family affluence, and grade and inclusive p-values for differences between boys and girls according to cluster allocation.

fn.p: Due to missing values, the numbers in some cells do not add up to the total base.

sec.p: The multinomial logistic regression analyses show the associations between cluster allocation, parental background, and FAS in boys and girls (Figure 1). The cluster profiles of multiple risk behaviour were associated with mixed background in boys. Boys of foreign background showed a higher association with the cluster profile of inadequate tooth brushing compared with boys of Swedish background. In boys, no significant association was shown between FAS and the cluster profiles. Both girls of mixed background and girls of foreign background showed an association with the cluster profile of multiple risk behaviour, the latter group also with the cluster profile of inadequate tooth brushing. Girls with low FAS showed associations with the cluster profiles of multiple risk behaviour and inadequate tooth brushing.

caption.p: Multinomial logistic regression with adjusted odds ratio (OR) and 99% confidence interval (CI) according to cluster allocation with low risk behaviour as reference category, against parental background with two Swedish-born parents as referents and family affluence (FAS) with high FAS as referents, adjusted for each other. *p-value <0.01.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The seven HRBs fell out into five clusters and the cluster of low-risk behaviour comprised half of the pupils. One of the differences between analysing the HRB as single behaviours and as cluster profiles is that associations with social dimensions are explored more clearly [1,5]. For example, in the present study, only girls’ HRB was associated with low FAS. Both girls of mixed background and girls of foreign background showed increased risk of allocation to the cluster profile of multiple HRB. This was also the case for boys of mixed background, but not for boys of foreign background.

More than half of the respondents in the cluster profile of inadequate tooth brushing were boys, which is in line with previous studies [2,20]. However, the multinomial analysis (Figure 1) in the present study showed associations with this cluster in both boys and girls of foreign background and in girls with low FAS. Some of the differences in tooth brushing frequency between pupils of Swedish-born parents and pupils of foreign background can be explained by the successful national dental health prevention programme established in Sweden in 1970 [19]. Investigations of dental health show high caries frequencies among children in countries from where people who migrated to Sweden originate [31].

sec.title: Gender perspectives
sec.p: Our study showed increased risk for girls of foreign extraction and low FAS to be allocated to the cluster profile of multiple HRB. These results could illuminate the specific threats that girls in general and especially girls of foreign extraction are exposed to. Examples are differences in expectations of boys’ and girls’ academic performance [32,33], responsibility for siblings, assisting in the household, and cultural social constructions of the gender role, which might lead to increased stress among the girls. These expectations are probably expressed as engagement in HRBs [6]. Sen and Östlin [8] describe how lack of an intersectional perspective in health research has significant human costs and how inequalities in health cannot solely be explained by socioeconomic position. They conclude that analyses of economic class without combination of gender analyses increase the risks of the results being misinterpreted and hiding social inequalities between men and women. These arguments by Sen and Östlin [8] might explain the associations found between low FAS in the cluster profiles of multiple HRB and inadequate tooth brushing in girls only. Our findings are similar to those reported by Gillander Gådin and Hammarström [18], which show associations between social indicators and HRBs among pupils in grade 9. In girls, parental foreign background, divorced parents, and unemployment were connected with low physical activity and weight concern. In boys, divorced parents and low parental support were connected with frequent smoking and drunkenness.

sec.title: Foreign extraction
sec.p: Fragility due to bicultural stress might partly explain the increased risk for girls of foreign extraction and boys of mixed background being allocated to the cluster profile of multiple risk behaviour in the present study. In the study by Fryer et al. [6], concepts of fragility due to belonging to a family with parents of two different ethnic origins are deduced as reasons behind the increased risk of HRB among adolescents of mixed background. One example of fragility is lack of belonging to a natural peer group, which might press the adolescent to engage in risky behaviours to achieve confirmation [6]. While society signals one social norm and the family another, boys and girls of mono-ethnic families usually manage to deal with it according to the families’ own decisions [12]. However, that was not the case for girls of foreign background in the present study. In families with one parent of the majority population and one parent of an ethnic minority, the boys and girls have to deal with both social norms in parallel [6], both in the family and in the community.

sec.title: Limitations and strength
sec.p: One of the weaknesses of cluster analyses is the risk of missing values as the analyses need completely filled questionnaires. However, our study had 11,082 respondents in the final analysis and the total number of respondents missed due to lack of information was low. The 6.3% (n=750) of the respondents were excluded in the cluster analysis. This group contained 56% boys, 12.8% of foreign background and FAS levels similar to the pupils who were included in the final analysis. The main reason for exclusion of participants was missing values on certain HRBs, e.g. smoking, soft-drink consumption, and vegetable consumption. In the final analysis, an additional 1.1% (n=130) were excluded due to missing values of FAS. Lastly, 10 individuals did not fit in the cluster analysis and we are unfortunately not able to answer why. An obstacle for comparisons between our cluster analyses and those used in other studies is the differences in categorising boys and girls into subgroups. The proportion of pupils of mixed background and pupils of foreign background (Table I) corresponds with proportion in previous research [26]. In our study, we categorised boys and girls according to their parental background with no respect to a specific country of origin, as the material is too small for categorisation into such subgroups. In American studies, adolescents often are categorised into subgroups according to their own perception of ethnic belonging [6]. However, despite the fact that the USA has a rather large and multiethnic population as compared to Sweden, the US researchers also found that some ethnic groups are at risk of becoming too small for inclusion in the analyses, as in the research by Ding and Young [22], Weden and Zabin [11], and Romero et al. [10]. Some advantages of the use of cluster analyses are the possibilities to make distinctions between both HRB and demographic characteristics, as the cluster analyses categorise individuals instead of behaviour variables, as in, for example, factor analysis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In boys, the cluster analysis showed associations with inadequate tooth brushing and foreign background, and with multiple HRB and mixed background. In girls, the cluster analysis showed associations with multiple HRB and mixed respective foreign background, and in inadequate tooth brushing and foreign background. In girls, the clusters of multiple HRB and inadequate tooth brushing showed associations with low FAS. There is a need of prevention programmes in school health care that focus on signs and consequences of bicultural stress and low material welfare in the family. Results of cluster analyses also function as indicators of which HRB can be promoted in the same interventions and which HRB can follow in addition when an intervention focuses on a single HRB [6]. As weekly smoking showed associations with increased risk of allocation to the cluster profile of multiple HRB, prevention programmes against smoking which take socio-demographic indicators into account are needed.

ack.p: We would like to thank the Swedish National Institute of Public Health for allowing us access to the HBSC database.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
